questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
You are a Dynamics 365 for Customer Service system administrator.
You need to create service-level agreements (SLAs) to meet company requirements.
What SLA types should you use? To answer, drag the appropriate SLA types to the correct requirements. Each SLA type may be used once, more than once, or not at all. You may need to drag the split bar between panes or scroll to view content.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

comments.content:
There are only two type of SLA : Enhanced and Standard.
The standard SLAs have been deprecated and replaced with enhanced SLAs.

I Think both answers are Enhanced

discussion.content:
I beleieve the answer is incorrect for the "track the status and times of an SLA". It should be an enhanced SLA Type

With an Enhanced SLA:

Track SLA statuses and times right on the case form by default. These details are tracked through the SLA KPI Instance record type.

Add success actions to an SLA. For example, you may want to send communications internally or outside your organization when the SLA has succeeded. Success actions are initiated only when the success condition is met on time, not when it is breached.

Answer to both the questions is "Enhanced SLA", MS docs clearly mentioned:

- Add success actions to an SLA. For example, you may want to send communications internally or outside your organization when the SLA has succeeded. Success actions are initiated only when the success condition is met on time, not when it is breached.

- Track SLA statuses and times right on the case form by default. These details are tracked through the SLA KPI Instance record type.

MS Docs Reference: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/customer-service/define-service-level-agreements

This is the clearest resource I've found on the differentiators of Enhanced SLAs. https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/customerengagement/on-premises/admin/enhanced-service-level-agreements?view=op-9-1

This answer is incorrect. a KPI is not an SLA type - it's a component of an Enhanced SLA, therefore the first answer should also be Enhanced.

Furthermore, 'Standard' SLA's have been deprecated. There is only one valid 'SLA type' option for this question. The answer is 'Enhanced' for both.

Hey do mention in the docs provided that:
"KPIs help you get timely warnings about any issues your customer support team might be having."

Therefore, by assumption, the first answer could be right. and the second one is definitely Enhanced.
Answer for both is Enhanced

Answer is Enhanced for both questions.
Success Action is supported by Enhanced SLA

whereas Success Criteria is suuported by Standard SLA

Enhanced SLA: Timers are automatically created and added to the case form with their statuses and failure and warning times visible.

https://www.dynamixacademy.com/dynamics-365-standard-service-level-agreements/

Question is asking ""what SLA types should you use"", there are only 2 types of SLA- STANDARD & ENHANCED, So the both the answer are - ENHANCED, REF:https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/customer-service/define-service-level-agreements
i think answers are correct and for sla kpi https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/customer-service/define-service-level-agreements#create-sla-kpis
Both are Enhanced

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/customer-service/define-service-level-agreements
Both have answer Enhanced SLA , refer above , both are the feature of Enhanced

There are only 2 types of SLA and KPI is not one of them.

reference: https://crmbook.powerobjects.com/basics/service-management-overview/service-level-agreements/
both are Enhanced
I think the same. There only two types of SLAs, and KPI is not one of them.

choices.A: Configure the scope of the workflow
choices.D: Request an administrator to add the SLA field to the entity form

questions.question_text:
Customer service representatives are not able to manually add service-level agreements (SLAs) to a record.
You need to enable on-demand SLAs.
What should you do?

discussion.content: "To apply SLAs on-demand manually, choose the SLA in the SLA field. This field is not available by default on entity forms. Ask your system administrator to add the field on the entity form."

comments.content: Seems pretty clearly D!

discussion.content: D. Request an administrator to add the SLA field to the entity form

Selected Answer: D
Correct Answer is D.
correct

Correct Answer is D.

To manually apply SLAs on demand, choose the SLA in the SLA field. This field isn't available by default on entity forms; you need to ask your system administrator to add it.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/customer-service/define-service-level-agreements

SLA on Case Form is not there by default.
You have to customize the Case form to get that field on Form.
The Given Answer D is Correct

comments.content: Actually yes that make sense. I believe you are right. So it should be C, D, A, B. I think.

discussion.content: I think Publish should be stage 2 - when setting up the SLA, you need to select an existing calendar.

comments.content:
Ok I was about to hate on this comment. But then actually tested this myself and its true..
For some reason you don't need to publish. I enabled Account for SLA, and added a lookup to SLA KPI instance. I was then able to create a SLA KPI and SLA without publishing the changes..
Bizarre. And a stupid question.
I agree, I tested it as well on a fresh install. The account entity is available for SLA and the new status reason is on the list **without** publishing. So the order is right.

discussion.content: I was sceptical, but the answers are right. The activation of the SLA for the account entity and the new values for the Status Reason field are available in the SLA without publishing the changes / default solution.
Agree, should publish the account first

comments.content: And measures no actual skill required to actually be good at your job... Gotta love MS exams :)

discussion.content: Ah, yes. The typical ExamTopics discussion forum where people are in massive disagreement on the answers.
C D A B - 100%
CDAB as per shrutzin - the business hours need to eb set

I think the answer is correct.
In step 4: Publish the account customization. I think that we must customize Main Form and add Quick View (for SLA KPI field) and set Timer for this field. After that, we must publish the account customization.

You don't need to publish when you enable SLA at the entity level however we still need to publish after you add the new status reason fields so that it will be available under account statuses. so C-D-A-B
C D A B

Arki is right, I just tested it now.

Step 1: I tried to create an SLA for the account entity - this was not possible, as "Case" was the only option available when creating the SLA.
Step 2: In the account entity, I enabled the SLA option. I did *not* publish the change.
Step 3: I tried to create the new SLA for account. This time, the entity account was available as an option, along with Case.

comments.content: thanks for trying this a good explanation. most people are saying C, D, A, B, so i am still skeptical. can explain all four steps you only have 3 steps listed? i don't see a publish step in your answer. can someone else also confirm?

i did the same exercise as Iakshmi and after saving the account modifications within the solution, it automatically published it.

So for me, C, D, A, B is also correct.

Arki & lakshmi are right in that we don't need to explicitly publish account entity after enabling SLAs, BUT we do need to define the business hours so that the SLA would take that into consideration of the business 8 hours mentioned in the question. Which is why the answer given is not right and the correct sequence should be CDAB.
The business hour defined first doesn't affect SLA, so D can actually be 2nd, 3rd, or 4th. In fact it really doesn't matter?

discussion.content: C D A B
C,D,A,B is correct ..you have to enable the entity first for SLAs, then publish what you just did, Create the SLA and then set the Warning/Failure at the bottom of the SLA page …

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
You are a Dynamics 365 for Customer Service administrator. Your company provides support between 9 a.m. and 5 p.m.
You must add a warning to account records when service representatives do not contact an account within eight business hours of the account being verified.
You need to enable service-level agreements (SLAs) for accounts.
In which order should you perform the actions? To answer, move all actions from the list to the answer area and arrange them in the correct order.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

comments.content: I agree, last option should be "Both standard and enhanced SLA". Reference: https://nishantrana.me/2014/10/29/differences-between-standard-sla-and-enhanced-sla-in-crm-2015/
nice so the answer is both, enhanced, both then?

discussion.content:
Last option "Configure KPI warnings and warning action" I think it's true for both standard and enhanced SLAs.

"-Add success actions to an SLA. For example, you may want to send communications internally or outside your organization when the SLA has succeeded. Success actions are initiated only when the success condition is met on time, not when it is breached."

Failure and Warning Actions are available for both.
correct answer should be : both, enhanced, both
This question was on the exam.

comments.content: This is ridiculous.. Standard SLAs are deprecated. Why do they include this on exams still

discussion.content: standard is deprecated

Answer : Both, Enhanced, Both Ref : Create Standard SLA & Enhanced SLA.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/customer-service/define-service-level-agreements#create-sla-kpis

both
enhanced
both?
Seems correct to me.

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You are a Dynamics 365 for Customer Service administrator.
Your company is trying to determine whether it needs to use standard or enhanced service-level agreements (SLAs).
You need to configure SLAs based on the requirements.
Which type of SLAs should you use? To answer, select the appropriate option in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

comments.content: indeed. Test it first. The only "edition" you can do while the entitlement is active is removing one type of support, but not edit the amount of units. Answer is for me B D.
Good good B&D

discussion.content: It should be B D. Test it for yourself before adding notes to not make it harder for people studying

A is definitely out, as per https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/customer-service/create-entitlement-define-support-terms-customer#activate-or-deactivate-an-entitlement. It says:

"If the end date is in the past, the entitlement is set to Expired."

It further says: 

"When an entitlement is active, you can’t edit it. To deactivate an entitlement so you can edit it, on the command bar, select Deactivate."

This leads me to believe that D would require deactivation.

The scenario that is less clear to me is B. Looking here https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/customer-service/create-entitlement-define-support-terms-customer#renew-an-entitlement, it says:

"To renew a canceled or expired entitlement, open the entitlement, and then on the command bar, select Renew."

I believe then as long as the current entitlement has expired, there is no need to deactivate the entitlement to renew into a new one. So probably B is out.

Based on the above, I would assume the correct answer is therefore just D.

comments.content:
For B I think the terminology 'renew' is throwing people off. The customer wishes to increase their entitlement terms, i.e. increase the number of support hours. The only way to do that is to deactivate the entitlement, update the terms and activate again. This is not about renewing an expired or canceled entitlement. Its about updating the terms of an active entitlement.
Answer is B&D

discussion.content:
A: Is wrong. If the entitlement is ended it is already deactivated.
B: Is wrong. You can only renew entitlements that are expired or canceled. I actually did try this.
D: Correct if you want to change the ' Total Terms' of an entitlement you need to deactivate the entitlement
E: Also wrong notes are being added to the timeline and thus can be added while the entitlement itself is readonly.

Selected Answer: BD
I m sure that b is correct, to renew entitlement, system cancel the first (tested)
D is correct : New Entitlement Channels" only becomes available when entitlement is deactivated first.

The answer is correct. It is D & E. In order to change anything on an entitlement one must deactivate it. Both D and E requires deactivation of the Entitlement. It is definitely not B. Usually once the Entitlement is expired and a user needs to renew it. It will create a copy of the old Entitlement for you to adjust the dates, etc.

B is not possible, because there are only 5 states: Draft, Waiting, Active, Expired, Cancelled.
I tried to renew the Entitlements, but the system returns this as an error: 
You can renew only the entitlements that are expired or canceled.
You can deactivate only entitlements that are active or waiting.
So , you don't have to deactivate an entitlement to renew it.

Selected Answer: BD
b & d. renewing brings into draft status where you can modify as needed

E is incorrect, I just tested it out 12/05/2021 I didn't need to deactivate the entitlement 

definitely B and D as stated in the comments

Not A: as its automatically deactivate after the expiration time over.
B: Because you cant add any hours or time without deactivating it first.
Not C: its just the visual confirmation, no need for deactivation.
D: Again same as B
Not E: you can definitely add notes without deactivating Entitlement.
So B & D only

comments.content: For B, the question answer suggests the entitlement is already in a deactivated/expired state in order for someone to renew the entitlement. I would say only D for the reason that its not possible to deactivate a already deactivated/expired entitlment.
Right thanks!

discussion.content: I can add notes when entitlement is activated, but can not change Description, Description is different than notes, so do not miss between them, The answer is only D
The only correct answer is D. Because the renew button is only shown when the entitlement is canceled or expired.

comments.content: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/customer-service/create-entitlement-define-support-terms-customer

discussion.content:
Answers should be B and D.

B - tested
Had to deactivate first to make changes to the date and/or hours.

D - tested
Had to deactivate to amend Entitlement Channels. "New Entitlement Channels" only becomes available when entitlement is deactivated first.

E - tested
Can add a note whilst activated. Did not need to deactivate to do this.

comments.content:
Correction to my comment on Option B. Changes the dates so that status becomes expired. Then the Renew button shows. There is no option to Deactivate. So only valid answer here is D.
The question also doesnt mention to choose more than one answer otherwise it would have stated so.

discussion.content: Tested 5/31/20 - C must deactivate to edit channel. D - incorrect - you CAN enter a note while the entitlement is active.
B is out of scope as we cannot deactivate expired entitlement. So I vote only D
Agree B & D Only
I am sure the answer is B and D.
Correct answers are B and D.
I vote only D
answer should be B and D. You can't change the date or total terms without deactivating

Answer is only D.
In E notes are allowed without deactivation and rest all options don't required deactivate which is required except in D.

Its B and D. 
E notes can be edited even for an activated entitlement and A is automatically expired
Sorry - Not A, if the entitlement went out of its date range it wold automatically move in to the 'expired' state.
Agree with rsilva - A,B,D
Its possible to add a note even when the entitlement is activated. I think B is the correct one.

choices.A: A customer's entitlement has ended and no more support is desired.
choices.C: A customer calls and wants to know how many hours of support remain.
choices.D: The customer must change remaining support hours from all email support to one-half email support and one-half phone support.
choices.E: You need to add notes to the customer's entitlement.
choices.B: A customer renews an entitlement for 100 more hours or one year.

questions.question_text:
You are a Dynamics 365 for Customer Service administrator.
You need to deactivate entitlements.
When should you deactivate entitlements? Each correct answer presents a complete solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
